questions.question: Which of the following accurately describes Sampson's theory for endometriosis?
Which of the following statements is false about endometriosis?

options.B: More common in nulliparous women.In utero exposure to DES increases riskd) Most common site is the cervixQuestion 3:Which of the following is the most common symptom associated with endometriosis?a) Dysmenorrheab) Dyspareunia

questions.explanation: The most common site of occurrence of endometriosis is the ovary. Endometriosis of the ovary isknown as endometrioma.By definition, endometriosis is the occurrence of benign endometrial tissue (glands andstroma) outside the cavity of the uterus. Endometriosis can occur anywhere in the body (exceptspleen) including the abdominal wall, lung, pleura, brain, etc.It is a proliferative, hormone-dependent disease of the childbearing period. Women between theage groups of 30-40 years are most commonly affected. Risk factors for endometriosis are asfollows:• Family history (7-10x risk with a 1st-degree relative)• Nulliparity646• In utero exposure to Diethylstilbestrol (DES)• Estrogen dependent conditions/Estrogen therapy• Immunological factor - Impaired T cell and NK cell activity and altered immunology in a womanmay increase the susceptibility to proliferation and growth.

questions.question: In a patient diagnosed with endometriosis, which of the following symptoms would you notexpect?
questions.explanation: Patients diagnosed with endometriosis are not likely to present with vaginal discharge.Clinical features of endometriosis include:•About 30% of the patients are asymptomatic.•The classic symptom complex includes:• Dysmenorrhoea•• Dyspareunia• Menorrhagia•Infertility (30-40%)•Dysmenorrhoea - most common symptom• Dyspareunia - occurs when the pouch of Douglas and rectovaginal septum are involved.•• Deep-seated pelvic pain•• Premenstrual and postmenstrual spotting

questions.question: A 26-year-old lady presented with complaints of severe pain on menstruation and heavy flow.She is subsequently diagnosed with endometriosis. The pain in this condition mainlycorrelates with
questions.explanation: Pain in endometriosis mainly correlates with the depth of penetration.Lesions penetrating more than 5mm are responsible for pain, dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia.The dysmenorrhea associated with endometriosis precedes menses by 24 to 48 hours and is lessresponsive to NSAIDs and combined OCPs.

questions.question: Arrange the following sites of endometriosis in the order of frequency of occurrence.
questions.explanation: 647The sites of endometriosis arranged in the order of frequency of occurrence are: Ovary > Pouchof Douglas > Broad ligament > Uterosacral ligament > Fallopian tube.Endometriotic lesions have been identified on all organs except the spleen.

questions.question: A middle-aged woman presented with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility. Onexamination, you note tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligaments. Which of the followingis the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligament pointstowards a diagnosis of endometriosis.The nodularity of the uterosacral ligament in endometriosis gives rise to the cobblestoneappearance seen on laparoscopy. This is referred to as 'sine qua non of endometriosis'.The below image shows the cobblestone appearance of the uterosacral ligament.Endometriosis - uterosacral ligamentNote: Endometrioma or chocolate cyst is endometriosis of the ovary. It presents as an adnexalmass.

questions.question: 640A young woman presented to your clinic with complaints of painful menstruation andpostmenstrual spotting. On examination, you note tender nodules in the posterior fornix anda fixed retroverted uterus. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation toconfirm the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of dysmenorrhea with tender nodules in the posterior fornix and aretroverted uterus is suggestive of endometriosis. The gold standard investigation for thediagnosis of this condition is a visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histologicalconfirmation. It is also the investigation of choice for the condition.Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:• Detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis• Locate the site of endometriosis and staging•⚫ To take biopsy648• To surgically treat endometriosis by ablationOther investigations for endometriosis include:•Estimation of CA-125 levels - raised in endometriosis.• Estimation of MCP-1 (Monocyte chemotactic protein) levels - raised in the peritoneal fluid ofwomen with endometriosis.

questions.question: A diagnostic laparoscopy was performed on a 27-year-old woman with severe dysmenorrhoea and dyspareunia. The following finding was seen on the pelvic peritoneum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical history and the image showing characteristic powder burn spots seen over the pelvic peritoneum on laparoscopy point toward a diagnosis of pelvic endometriosis. On laparoscopy, the typical endometriotic lesions appear like small black, dark brown or bluish dots. These are called powder burns or gunshot appearance of the serosal surfaces of the peritoneum. They are nodules or small cysts containing old haemorrhages surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis. Subtle appearances of endometriosis seen on laparoscopy are: Red flame-shaped areas, Red polypoid areas, Yellow-brown patches, White peritoneal plaques or scarring, Peritoneal defects known as Allen-Masters Syndrome, Subovarian adhesions. The lesions mentioned above are thought to be more active than the powder burn areas. Endometriotic lesions in the peritoneal cavity contain yellowish-brown fluid. This fluid contains prostaglandins that are responsible for the pain associated with this condition. Endometriosis of the ovary leads to formation of the chocolate cyst which is a true cyst with columnar epithelium lining. The image below shows the laparoscopic appearance of endometriotic lesions in the pouch of Douglas and on the right, the sacrouterine ligament. Dyspareunia occurs when the pouch of Douglas and rectovaginal septum are involved.

questions.question: In endometriotic lesions, histology represents its:
questions.explanation: In endometriotic lesions, histology represents its high estrogen activity. Endometriosis is defined by the presence of 'ectopic' endometrial tissue at a site outside of the uterus. Endometriosis is a proliferative hormone-dependent disease of the childbearing period. It is extremely rare before menarche and disappears after menopause. The endometriotic implants show certain differences when compared to normal endometrium. There is increased production of estrogen by endometriotic stromal cells due to high levels of the enzyme aromatase. This is absent in normal endometrial stroma. Management of endometriosis: Management of symptomatic endometriosis includes minimal invasive, medical, and surgical treatments. Drug treatment includes GnRH analogues, OCPS, Letrozole, Danazol, Gestrinone, and Anti-progesterone (Mifepristone) and Progesterone. Mnemonic: GOLD GAP. Laparoscopy involves destruction by cautery, laser vaporization, excision of cysts, adhesiolysis, and presacral neurectomy (LUNA - laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation). Laparotomy involves incision of chocolate cysts and removal of lining, salpingo-oophorectomy, hysterectomy, and unilateral or bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and excision of scar endometriosis.

questions.question: Which of the following operative procedures are least likely to be followed by scarendometriosis?
questions.explanation: Among the given operative procedures, hysterectomy is least likely to be followed by scarendometriosis.Operations most likely to be followed by scar endometriosis are:•⚫ Hysterotomy• Classical Cesarean section•Myomectomy• Ventrofixation (fixing uterus to the abdominal wall)•⚫ Episiotomy

questions.question: A 39-year-old nulliparous woman presented with dysmenorrhea and a progressively growing,painless abdominal mass. USG scan revealed a cystic lesion of the left ovary which wasexcised. The below image shows the excised specimen. Which of the following statements isfalse about this condition?

options.A: It is seen in endometriosis of ovary
options.B: It is lined by columnar epithelium
options.C: It is usually a bilateral condition642
options.D: It is a malignant cystic lesion

questions.explanation: The given clinical history and the image is suggestive of a chocolate cyst of the ovary which is abenign cystic lesion.Chocolate cysts of the ovary are a manifestation of endometriosis. Both the ovaries are usuallyaffected. On histology, the cyst is lined by columnar epithelium. Pseudoxanthoma cells are presentwhich are large macrophages or scavenger cells that appear brown in colour due to ingested bloodpigments such as haemosiderin. They are polyhedral in shape and resemble lutein cells.Given below is a gross image of the chocolate cyst of the ovary.Chocolate cyst - OvaryGiven below is a histopathological section of an endometriotic lesion showing thepseudoxanthoma cells.651EndometriosisPseudoxanthomacells

questions.question: A patient is being evaluated for chronic abdominal pain. Her lab reports revealed elevatedCA-125 levels. Which of the following conditions is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: CA-125 levels are not expected to be elevated in malignant pancreatic tumours.CA-125 is a glycoprotein and cell surface antigen. Its levels are raised in the following conditions:• Abdominal or pelvic tuberculosis• Pelvic inflammatory disease• Endometriosis•Malignant epithelial ovarian tumour•Chronic liver disease•2% of normal women, especially during menstruation.Endometrioma refers to ovarian endometriosis. CA-125 levels are raised to more than 35 U/mL in80% of cases of endometriosis. The level is directly proportional to the extent of the disease.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman with dyspareunia is diagnosed to have endometriosis. Which of thefollowing drugs is not useful for her treatment?
questions.explanation: Estrogen is not used in the treatment of endometriosis as the condition is estrogen-dependent.For minimal disease, the drug of choice is NSAIDs. Oral contraceptive pills are given if associatedmenstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrualflow.For moderate to severe disease, oral progestogens are the first drugs to be started. They areknown to antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium causing endometrial atrophy. Thedrug of choice is GnRH agonists.652Management of symptomatic endometriosisMinimal invasiveMedicalSurgerysurgery•Drug treatmentG-GnRH analogue⚫O-OCPS. L-Letrozole...D - DanazolG-GestrinoneA-Anti progesterone -MifepristoneP-ProgesteroneMnemonic: GOLD GAP•..LaparoscopyDestruction by cautery,laser vapourizationExcision of cystAdhesiolysisPresacral neurectomyLUNA (laparoscopicuterosacral nerveablation)LaparotomyIncision of chocolate cyst,and removal of lining⚫ Salpingo-oophorectomy• Hysterectomy andunilateral or bilateralsalpingo-oophorectomyExcision of scarendometriosisNote: The best time to conceive in a patient with endometriosis is immediately after surgery.

questions.question: A patient with endometriosis requires treatment with GnRH analogues. She is scared ofinjections so you plan to prescribe a nasal preparation for her. Which of the following GnRHagonists could you prescribe?
questions.explanation: The GnRH agonist available as a nasal preparation for the treatment of endometriosis is nafarelin.GnRH analogues are used in the management of endometriosis and are given by continuousadministration. This suppresses the secretion of pituitary gonadotropins and leads to atrophy ofthe endometrial tissue in 90% of cases.Leuprolide and triptorelin are GnRH agonists which are given IM. Goserelin is available as adepot preparation.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding adenomyosis?
questions.explanation: Patients with adenomyosis commonly present with symptoms of menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea.Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of theendometrium directly into the myometrium. It usually occurs following vigorous curettage,repeated childbirth or in conditions with an excess of estrogen. Adenomyosis is more common inmultiparous women aged 40 years and above. They commonly present with menorrhagia anddysmenorrhea. Other symptoms include pelvic discomfort, backache and dyspareunia.On per-vaginal examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uteruscorresponding to 12-14 weeks size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination. This isknown as Halban's sign.Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical assessment. A diagnostic hysteroscopy combinedwith curettage is the initial step in the management because of menorrhagia.Total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localised excision and levonorgestrel containingIUCD can be tried in younger patients.653The image below is an illustration of adenomyosis.AdenomyosisThe image below shows adenomyosis as seen during laparoscopy. The uterus is soft and enlarged;the blue spots represent subserous endometriosis.Adenomyosis

questions.question: A patient with menorrhagia and backache is diagnosed with adenomyosis. Which of thefollowing is not associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: Adenomyosis is not associated with sub involution of the uterus.Uterine subinvolution is impaired or retarded involution of the uterus. It is associated withuterine fibroid, cesarean section and conditions causing overdistension of the uterus like twinpregnancies or polyhydramnios.Adenomyosis often coexists with the following conditions:• Uterine fibromyomas654• Pelvic endometriosis (15%)• Endometrial carcinoma

questions.question: A 43-year-old multiparous woman presented with menorrhagia and secondary dysmenorrhea.On examination, Halban's sign was positive. The transvaginal USG findings are given below.Which of the following is the definitive treatment for her condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette and the transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) showing the Venetian blindappearance is suggestive of adenomyosis. The definitive treatment for adenomyosis ishysterectomy.Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of theendometrium directly into the myometrium. Diagnosis is mainly based on clinicalassessment. Painful, symmetrical enlargement of the uterus is suggestive of adenomyosis. Onbimanual examination, the uterus is softened and tender. This is known as Halban's sign.TVS findings include salt and pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence ofsubendometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance. MRI can also be done fordiagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy isthe treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried inyounger women.Management of AdenomyosisManagement of AdenomyosisYoung women- Medical (NSAIDs)Hormonal (menorrhagia)- Mirena IUCD- Localized excisionOlder womenD/C for menorrhagiaNormalHysterectomy with orwithout bilateralsalpingo-OophorectomyOMARROWThe image below is of a sagittal MRI showing a uterus with adenomyosis in the posterior wall.Gross enlargement of the posterior wall is noted, with many foci of hyperintensity.655BPST 4513AHTR 3675.0TE: 109.0FA 160.0PFZoom: 1.2PEL Sag T2 FRFSE656
